header_summary:
The development of an autonomous and sustainable infrastructure for volunteer-driven projects is highlighted, focusing on diminishing dependency on specific individuals or hardcoded systems. This evolution aims at a self-sufficient model that accommodates the fluctuating volunteer participation, ensuring long-term viability and effectiveness. Such a shift underscores the project's commitment to adaptability and resilience, acknowledging the time required to manifest the full benefits of this system on the mainnet.

In the realm of Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs), particularly BIP 174 concerning Partially Signed Bitcoin Transactions (PSBTs), there's an ongoing effort to bolster privacy through silent payments. This initiative seeks to obscure transaction destinations, necessitating knowledgeable signers to avoid certain signature hash types that compromise the privacy of these transactions. Furthermore, the proposal to adjust PSBT global fields for better indicating silent payment outputs and streamlining the verification process signifies a move towards enhancing transaction privacy without sacrificing PSBT functionality.

The release of Bitcoin Core version v27.1 marks a significant update, incorporating bug fixes, performance improvements, and user interface enhancements tailored for a broad spectrum of operating systems. This version, accessible via [direct download links or BitTorrent](https://bitcoincore.org/en/download/), benefits from the collective input of numerous contributors, reflecting a community-driven effort to advance Bitcoin Core. Major updates include modifications to Miniscript, RPC commands, and GUI improvements, emphasizing the project's dedication to improving security, reliability, and user experience.

recent_posts.title: BIP352: PSBT support
recent_posts.summary:
- Silent payments enhance privacy in Bitcoin transactions by disguising the destination.
- Signers must avoid `ALL | ACP` hash types in transactions with silent payment outputs to maintain integrity.
- Proposals include adding flags for silent payments in PSBTs and restructuring verification processes.

today_in_history_posts.title: MAD-HTLC
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A technical report highlights HTLC's security depends on altruistic or myopic miners.
- Making bitcoind non-myopic required 150 lines of code, questioning its long-term viability.
- An alternative, MAD-HTLC, offers provable security, inviting team feedback with provided links.

today_in_history_posts.title: Dynamic Commitments: Upgrading Channels Without On-Chain Transactions
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The Lightning Network proposes updates allowing nodes to modify commitments without on-chain transactions.
- New protocol changes facilitate safer channel upgrades and the use of fresh Bitcoin features without altering the blockchain.
- These modifications support dynamic commitments and introduce a new `channel_type` to streamline funding negotiations and upgrades.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Passive and active investments are two main strategies, involving hands-off or direct management, respectively.
- Issues with passive investment include the principal/agent problem and potential market withdrawal effects.
- The blog explores stabilizing economies via a hybrid currency system, combining inflationary and deflationary approaches.
